intro: Gossypium harrisii, commonly known as the Hawaiian cotton or Kūpūpū, is a flowering plant native to the Hawaiian Islands. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its soft, fluffy fibers that resemble cotton. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 3 meters. Its flowers are usually pink or purple and are followed by small, round capsules containing the fibrous seeds. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, Gossypium harrisii is considered a rare and endangered species.
